content.description: Move right at the fourth bolt. Then climb the off width to gain ledge. Next a boulder sequence, into a difficult roof.
content.protection: 11-12 bolts, including anchors. It depends how many of the bolts you clip at the start.
content.location: To the right of Broken Bit. But it shares the same four start bolts as Broken Bit.

content.description: Start off the ledge 6 feet up and launch right into the boulder problem crux of the route, which involves moving right on small holds and then  up past the 2nd bolt to two small crimps.  The boulder problem culminates with a deadpoint up to a good flat hold at the 3rd bolt.  Big reaches to sloping holds deposit you at a wobbly jug for a good shake and a high reach to clip the 4th bolt.  Move left and pull a cool roll over move and continue up on small sloping crimps past 2 more bolts.  A second crux near the top involves pulling an the remnants of a bolted on flake and small sidepulls.  Moving up to the jugs on Hinterland is the last bit of this route and the difficulty backs off, its a bit run out when you are clipping the anchors but the fall is clean and the climbing is easy at this point.
content.protection: 6 bolts to rap rings.  I recommend stick clipping the second bolt because the clipping hold is small and it is a strenuous clip.  If you fall you are swinging into the jagged portion of the ledge.
content.location: In between Flippin' the Bird and Hinterland.

content.description: First two clips easily gained, then a difficult thing section crux to step climbing with better holds. And a final difficult section before the finish.
content.location: This is a second pitch climb. It can be accessed by  climbing the first pitch of The Streak ,or Alpine Line. So this pitch is located between the second pitch of The Streak and Alpine line.

content.description:
Two Screws is a somewhat funky and worthwhile variation to Groovin'.

 Climb past the first four bolts and technical crux of Groovin' to a no hands stance.  Continue straight up the corner passing two more bolts to the Twisted Sister anchor.  The crux is the sequence passing the last bolt to the anchor.  There is some less challenging, but non-trivial climbing to get there.
Between Laid Back & Groovin. Up thin crack to roof. Traverse right out roof to anchors. Sustained.
content.protection: 6 bolts. 2nd clip is hard, 3rd is scary.

content.description: One of the last routes at the big wall between Hinterland and Alpine Line. Starts on left facing ramp and follows the dihedral up towards the first anchors.  Follow the pocket and prow up and slightly right to the second set of anchors.  Careful as holds continue to break between the prow and the anchors.
content.protection: Six bolts to the first anchors, fixed draws from the first anchors to the second.
content.location: Located in the Big Wall area.

content.description: Start in a right facing dirty, short corner and move up the jugs past 2 bolts to a good stance.  Move up for 3 or 4 moves on Batman to gain the 3rd bolt on the right.  Move up and right on thin holds and a technical sequences (crux) past 4 bolts to a good incut flake for a good rest.  Continue up past 1 more bolt on positive holds to the anchor.
content.location: The dirty inside corner to the left of Groovin'

content.description: A good portion of this route fell down recently, and is no longer climbable until new bolts are placed.

The Streak (whose first pitch is the same as Opposing Gravity's) is an apt description of this butt stain of a route. The holds are large. Follow up the right angling ramp onto the face. Careful for loose rock on the ramp (even still in 2010).
content.protection: 4 bolts, anchors just out of sight above large finishing jug, down and right of the visible hanging chains. Bring longer draws or runners to hang over the finish hold.
content.location: Big Wall, route immediately right of the Hinterland streak. There is a prominent right angling ramp.  Don't follow the ramp up Alpine Line.

content.description: at the chain on The Streak either bust left traversing on the ledge towards Hinterland and go up to a very interesting roof encounter, or continue up the refrigerator block and head left immediately afterwords. Going left seems to be a bit harder, but continuing up the streak seems to be the most popular. from there work your way up some powerful reaches on crimps and side pulls. Avoid going to far right and using holds on the streak to skip the crux. This is definitely the best route on the wall and deserves more attention. The first ascent history is a little murky and it seems there are two accounts. It sat untouched for quite a long time with its original bolts and some manky fixed draws,but it was rebolted in the winter of 2014 and now has nice steel fixed draws. Since its revival its seen quite a few repeats, including a flash by Vasya Vorotnikov.
content.location: Between the upper halves of Hinterland and The Streak. Identified by fixed draws with red gates

content.description: Hard climb up to the thrid bolt, after that it's sustained but it's big holds.

Climb the past the fist set of anchors past 4 bolts, the crux is above the 2nd bolt, with some slight leftward traversing moves with bad feet.  The final move of the crux requires getting a high foot while holding a bad pinch and an OK sidepull.
content.protection: 6 bolts to the first anchors, 4 bolts to the second anchors.
content.location: Same start as Hinterland, next to the Streak

content.description: This is the first pitch. There's a rap station 1/2 way up the wall before things turn steep. Two Cruxes and continuous climbing make this a fun pitch.  There are a few glued on holds, notably the jug at the 3rd clip which also features a big X.

Angles up and right to a good rest below a short, left-facing corner.  Clip the bolt on the face left of the corner, not the old one on the right side of it.  Technical crux is getting up this corner to the good holds above (and a bolt near the top of the corner). 

  From there head out right on good hands.  Head up before working back left near the top.  The upper section has good holds and fun moves - don't get pumped out before the anchors. 

  I found the anchors tricky to clip, but maybe I'm missing something or was just too pumped.
content.location: On the left side of the big wall, right of Laid Back... and Twisted Sister.

content.description:
Powerful movement from start to finish. The entire climb is hard, but the crux is probably moving through the sharp edges guarding the chains.  

  It is possible to link this route up with Hinterland? for a much longer climb.
content.protection: 5 or so bolts to chains. The protection and anchor bolts are probably due for replacement.

content.description: Climb "Flippin the Bird" into "Opposing Gravity", instead of clipping the anchor on flippin, clip the bolt on "Welcome" to the right, pull the redpoint crux of that, and continue to the first anchor of "Hinterland", get a good rest on the flake above, and head to the first fixed draw of "Opposing"
content.protection: 3 or 4 draws for Flippin, bring 2 long draws for the traverse. For the first ascent alpine draws eliminated all rope drag.
content.location: climbs the entirety of "Flipping the Bird" and "Opposing Gravity".

content.description: Easy climbing diagonaling left leads up to powerful moves up two underclings with terrible feet to more powerful/long moves climbing on drilled pockets above.  The last bolt is a little spaced below the anchors but it shouldn't be a big deal as the falls are clean.
content.location: The first route on the Big Wall, to the left of romania.

content.description: Great climb, well bolted. Anchors were recently replaced. Nice line.
More loose rock than your favorite Alpine Route. Belayers beware!
content.protection: Climber: 7 bolts to first anchor.   Belayer: Helmet & riot shield

content.description:
The Big Wall of Birdsboro Quarry.  

  A 60m rope will do fine with the lower offs here. It's not really two pitches... it's just got first anchors and second anchors.
